reviews.review_text: Vintage Burke. What's not to love?
If you haven't read any of these you are missing some great books.  I have now read the complete series and wishing there were more.

I've read one other book by James Lee Burke and I enjoyed both very much. It's more than a crime novel, it's a history lesson combined with truths of life he has learned and shares with intense compassion with his readers. I'm sure I will read and enjoy every book written.
Simply fantastic.  Burke never disappoints in Robicheaux series.
It's James Lee Burke.  Moving and atmospheric as usual.

James Lee Burke is a favorite author of mine. Loved much of his work, but this one is  a mess. If you like endless  maudlin worrying about mortality and endless liberal griping and an endless series of disconnected scenes then this book is for you. But remember, others have said, and I agree, it has a very thin and very unbelievable  plot. To me the conclusions (there were mind-numbing botches)  left me scratching my head. Halfway through I wondered where and how the myriad characters were going and how this jumble  was going to come together. . We have a delusional Dave Robicheaux pondering and fearing death--not just once or twice. Throughout we get his lengthy  introspective on meeting his mother and father on a old time river boat. Vietnam death memories come to play.  In the end Clete joins in Dave's  fears.  Perhaps it's because the writer is approaching his eighth decade (born 1936) as he admits in the book. Alafair has grown up and once again makes friends with unsavory people, including murderers. Except for one scene, Alafair is tiresome. Molly is disgusted with Dave's illusions. Clete going over the top with violence.  As a cop, Dave  lets an admitted murderer slide. There is the old  Nazi war criminal with his own agenda who  wants to kill  Dave, and  oil men who put hits on not only Dave, but Alafair and Molly--which was known to them but they seem to shrug it off. . The oil men are there because of the gulf oil blowout.  The usual creeps like child abusers, women femme fatales,  Mafia figures portrayed as dum-dums, crooked, rapist cops, down-and-out blacks, teen savants, drinkers, rotten corporations that are ruining the wetlands,  helpful hookers, and jolly drug dealers show up. The over-the-top scenes  could not support all these characters resulting in an unsatisfactory story. .
Long book, rather lame subject matter but the writing is terrific. Glad i finished it.

summary:
Book 19/20 in the Robicheaux Series

“America’s best novelist” James Lee Burke returns with another New York Times bestselling entry in the Dave Robicheaux thriller series (The Denver Post).

Set against the events of the Gulf Coast oil spill, rife with “the menaces of greed and violence and man-made horror” (The Christian Science Monitor), Creole Belle finds Dave Robicheaux languishing in a New Orleans recovery unit since surviving a bayou shoot-out. 

The detective’s body is healing; it’s his morphine-addled mind that conjures spectral visions of Tee Jolie Melton, a young woman who in reality has gone missing. An iPod with an old blues song left by his bedside turns Robicheaux into a man obsessed…And as oil companies assign blame after an epic disaster threatens the Gulf’s very existence, Robicheaux unearths connections between tragedies both global and personal—and faces down forces that can corrupt and destroy the best of men.

"All the characters . . . are superbly drawn, and the plot is heart-pounding . . . sure to be embraced by author James Lee Burke's fans." The Washington Post"
